quote: Ahadi na mithaki ni  deni katika haki.
tail: JKP. A promise and a vow are debts indeed. Mithaki: having strength, having perfection. 4260. Ahadi [ni] deni. J.,ahadi; B.1.52; T.6; SACL. 45; MARA.2; SAM.26.; V.4. A promise is a debt. Ahadi ni deni, na deni ijuzie. SACL. 196; JKP. A promise is a debt, and a debt obliges. Juzia: to be obliged.

quote: Ahadi ni mtu, msi  ahadi si mtu.
tail: JKP. [Keeping] a promise is [being] a real human, one who does not [keep a promise] is not a real person.
AL,hatima; AL 1540; AL 1541. A promise is nothing, wait for its fulfillment. AL 1541 has baadaye, afterwards, instead of hatima.
JKP. Promises have obligations.
EM.8.4. One who knows much does not say much. Ajuaye mengi husema machache. NGU. The one who knows much says little.

quote: Alindaye  ulimi wake, alinda nafsi yake.
tail: NGU. People who watch their tongue take care of [guard] their soul.
JKP. Praise a good person, keep silent about a bad one.
JKP. People who are told tall stories, have their own to tell. "Said when a story is not believed." JKP.
A.173; T.22; SACL. 234. It is the tongue that bound its owner What was said lightly has come to pass, and has caught up with that person.

quote: Msi hadhari  hujifunga kwa ulimi wake.
tail: SAM.16.21. If you are careless, you bind yourself with your tongue. Cf. #1841.
KS mavi. That person came here to tell dirt. Mavi: excrement, nonsense.
NGU. [The animal] that roars is not the one that will eat meat. cf. # 1852; # 1852.
ED.16.24. A person who cannot take a joke is no joker. Don't make jokes on people if you cannot take a joke yourseIf. Cf. #1883.

quote: Aso  hasanati wala thawabu hufungwa kitaya kama  rikabu.
tail: KS.,rikabu. People who have no kindness or gifts have their jaw tied like a camel's. Hasanati or hisani: kindness, favor, goodness. Thawabu: God-given gifts, rewards. Rikabu: an animal used for riding; a camel, horse, donkey. Kitaya: lit., a small jaw. Tia tayani mwa punda: put the bridle on a donkey's jaw.
RSP.39. For a person who understands, half a greeting is enough.

quote: Binadamu  ana macho mawili, masikio mawili na mdomo mmoja.
tail: EM.28.16. A human being has two eyes, two ears, but one mouth. Watch and listen twice before speaking once. EM.
RSP.61. Study is better than talking.
JKP. The only useful things are those that can be put in a pot and eaten. "Said by a wife to an unemployed, loquacious husband." JKP. Cf. #1830.
H.98; B.2.36; MARA 3. A half empty tin never fails to make noise. Empty vessels make the most sound. People with little knowledge talk most.
MARA 3. A half filled tin does not stop shaking.
EM.47.11. An empty tin cannot stop sounding.

F.8. 5- B.2.42. An empty tin never stops making noise. Debe shinda: half-empty tin; is used figuratively for bastards and people of low offspring. In Swahili custom it is very bad for a woman to have a baby out of wedlock. That child is called mwana haramu (a bastard) and whenever that person does something bad or shameful or lacks good behavior, this proverb is mentioned. This proverb is used to show that if you want to know a person look at his deeds and behavior.

EM.47.12. Democracy is not domocracy. Actions, not mere words. Democracy is a way of life, and freedom and discipline are its bases. Domocracy is to rule by mere talk, a lot of words without actions. EM. Domocrasie: a word formed with mdomo (mouth).

quote: Fikara  ndogo hufanya mtu aseme sana.
tail: NGU. Little thoughtfulness causes a person to say too much.
EM g8. Much talk, many lies. Cf. #1834, #1850.

EM g7. Talk is the asusa of a journey. "Asusa is the snacks which are taken while having drinks to enable a person to take a lot of drinks without harming the body. It weakens the power of the drinks. Conversation during a journey makes the traveler forget the difficulties and the distance of the journey without getting tired too soon. Cf. Make short the miles with talk and smiles." EM. Asusa: n. food of any description eaten when drinking beer, spirits &c., but usu. well-cooked meat." Johnson.
T.71; J.,shindo. News always comes with a kind of shock.
T.71; KB.,kishindo; SACL.407. News from far comes with Ã©clat. T.

quote: Habari ya  mbalamwezi, kung'aa na kufifia.
tail: PM.85. News of the full moon, to shine and to fade away. Do not believe all the rumors one hears in the evening; in the morning, they fade away.
KB.58. There is no scar for slander. Moral evil cannot be cured.
JKP. Nothing will be of any use, neither male nor female. "Too much talking." JKP.
EM h8. No word is spoiled if the lips stay together. Cf. #1219A; Contrast #1821A, #1824.
T.83; B.1.29. So and So has no lining to the tongue.
T.85. To the words of a gossiper nothing is added.
AL 619, Al,fa. One does not kill oneself for what people say. All words should be taken with a grain of salt. Words are not reliable enough.
AL,haya; AL 1572. For being overly shy, the mouth get crooked. Too shy to speak up. Of one who is too servile, without defending oneself. AL. Cf. #1206.

AL 1524; AL,kwale, mno. Haya ya mno ilimwisha kwale. AL 1525. Too much shame killed the partridge. The partridge died of hunger because it did not ask for food or shelter. This is also sometimes said ironically when somebody overeats. Cf.#1206.

quote: Heri  kukunguwaa kidole kuliko kukunguwaa ulimi.
Heri  kujikunguwaa kidole kuliko kujikunguwaa ulimi.
tail: F. 11 16; B.1.29; MARA 3; BM 5; KS; MARA 3.

quote: Heri kwaa ya  dole kuliko kwaa ya ulimi.
tail: KS.,kwaa. Better to stumble with the toe than with the tongue.

quote: Heri kukuwaa kwa  guu kama kwa ulimi.
tail: ED.90. Better to stumble with the foot than with the tongue. The toe may be very painful, but the harm the tongue can do, can bring much greater pain and trouble. EM. Bruising your toe is your pain, but your tongue hurts other people. It's difficult to soften other people's pain. MARA.
KS,kunguwaa. A person stumbles a toe, but not the tongue.

quote: Hicho ni  chuo cha mwangoma, cha majini pepo: endao kifyoma hukiacho papo.
tail: T.93. This is the book of Mwangoma about the demons: the person who is going to read it, leaves it forthwith. About an unpleasant subject of conversation, which you would rather not enlarge on. T.
RSP.10. Tolerate a joke, there is no wound in it. It does not hurt. RSP. Cf. #46.

quote: Huamba  ulimi, ni mimi, ni mimi.
tail: RSP.16. The tongue says, it is me, it is me. Talkers always talk about themselves. RSP.
ZO 254. So and So refused you food, but did not stop you speaking.
JKP. He talks like a cymbal. A chatterbox. JKP. Upatu: a dish-shaped gong.
FSP.56. You cannot think, without holding your tongue.
EM j9. A big barking dog does not bite. A person who talks a lot and threatens others does not harm others.
JKP. A cock will crow to a cock, when he crows the other one will crow too. "People will gossip, and what one person says will go around."JKP. Jimbi, jogoo: cock. Tawikia for atawikia: will crow.
NGU. The clever rooster crows. It is the work of the rooster to crow in the morning. It is its duty. Let people know what you can do, what you are worth. Saa ya shamba : the clock in the village.

JKP. A pen [a word] that has spoken brings the event nearer. JKP. "A word spoken in anger may cause unwanted reactions." JKP. Kurubia for karibia: come close, approach. Pate dialect. Jiri for fika: come. Kalamu: a pen (a pen is used to write words). Iambiweyo for yaambiwayo: what is said.
KS, ambika. She put on a mortar and holds on to the pestle. Of someone who interferes with other people's business.
JKP. Everyone who has a need goes to the rubbish heap. "All people slander". JKP "The rubbish heap was and is also the latrine, in the middle of a group of houses, to be used collectively." JKP.
MA.187. Silence does not bring harm.
REK. Silence finished the trees in the forest. For not protesting the evil done.

quote: Kimya,  kimya si ujinga, ni maneno ya kupeleleza.
tail: MP.82.8 Silence is not necessarily foolishness, it could be spying. MP. Be suspicious of dormant waters. MP

F.15.21; V.,kimya; T.151; J.,kimya; JK.,mkubwa; RECH.207; KB.106; SACL 382; KA; KS, mshindo. Much silence has a mighty noise. A long silence is followed by a mighty noise. A too-long silence has harmful consequences. KB. A person who remains silent and does not contribute in daily conversation is considered very dangerous. Often such a person does fearsome things. KA.
JKP. Silence is a big noise. "Silence predicts storm, silence indicates your enemy is premeditating a big move." JKP.

quote: Kimya ni sifa ya maiti, yu hai husema.
tail: MA.188. Silence is an attribute of the dead, one who is alive speaks.

AL 1140. The mouth like a bell, the legs like the mayugwa. Those with nice words are not the ones who will pay. AL. Mayugwa: taro, a green vegetable, tasting like spinach when cooked. The plant has big leaves and the fragile long stems look like legs.
F.15.24; B.1.29; KA has kanwa instead of kinywa. The mouth is the home of words.

(V.,kinywa; T.126; SACL.,kanwa; KB.,jumbe; SACL.,jumbe 328. The mouth is the magistrate [ruler or master] of words. Or: The mouth is like a chief having under his orders the words of speech. KB; SACL. About the duty of controlling one's words. Cf.#? Watu ni gamba hawakosi la kwamba (KA) (under Women-Men) Jumba: big house, palace. Jumbe: chief, head person.
JKP. Grow up and see. "Said to a child who is asking too many questions." JKP.

quote: Kuambiliwa  kuna uwongo, mara kumi ukajionee.
tail: AL 624 Hearsay is full of error, go and see yourself even ten times.
NGU. Being told is not the same as understanding.
JKP. Speaking evil you will see it comes back. "Persons with evil tongues will soon find they are slandering themselves." JKP.
RSP.147. Talking, talking does not cure the cripple. Too many words serve no purpose. MM.
JKP. No need to say much. There is no need for many words.
JKP. To speak many words is not [winning] an argument.

quote: Kusema si hoja,  kazi ni kufanya.
tail: JKP. Talking is no necessity, the essence of the job is to get it done.

quote: Kusema ni  kuzuri, na kutosema ni kuzuri.
tail: Holiday. Speaking is good and silence is good

quote: Hotuba ni fedha  na kimya ni dhahabu.
tail: MEM.302. Speech is silver and silence is golden.
NGU. Speaking is not the same as doing.
NGU. Reading is not the same as being told.

quote: Kwamba  kwema kwenye shukurani ni kumpa mtu atakayo.
tail: JKP. Speaking good words of gratitude is giving a person what is needed.

quote: Kweli ya  mdogo si uwongo wa mkubwa.
tail: EM k39. A little person's truth is not [as acceptable as] the big person's lie. A little person may say the truth about something, but this will not be believed as well as the lies which an important person may say about it.
NGU. Going with fools and words never ends.
RSP.68. Just lick the honey, don't ask any questions. Cf. #166.
V.150; JKP. What is worth explaining, explain; what is not worth, swallow it. One who speaks little has little to answer for. V.
MARA 2. What is, is spoken about. People speak about the things that are present. So, don't do bad or stupid things, because people will speak about it. MARA.
MARA 3; KA. What is in the heart, the tongue steals. Secrets want to be told and often come out inadvertently.

JKP. Watch your tongue like a farmer [watches his crop]. "In Africa farmers must constantly watch their crops lest they are eaten by birds, monkeys or wild pigs. In the same way, the words we have spoken may be misused by our enemies to harm us." JKP.
EM l11. Bad language is soonest learned. It is easier to learn what is evil than what is good.
NGU. Bad language is like a stench.
. NGU. Still waters are deep.
FSM.93. Roaring water has no teeth. Barking dogs seldom bite. Cf. #1852.
V.50; STEERE, p.l94. Charcoals do not roast the meat. Dead embers do not roast meat. Fair words butter on parsnips.
MM. It is a surprise why the charcoal did not roast meat. Said of people who do not perform as well as they could.
T.233. Forty mouths are like forty spears.
. JK.131 Forty tongues, forty spears.
JKP. Ten tongues are ten javelins. Cf. #1860.

quote: Makukuu ya  tai si mapya ya kengewa.
tail: SACL. 857; KS,tai; AL 1186. The carrion, food of the big vulture, is not fresh meat for the hawk. The words of the old people have nothing pleasant for the young. SACL; AL.

quote: Mambo  yafaayo watu ni yangiayo chunguni.
tail: T.242; KB, chungu; SACL.156. The matters which are of use to people are those which go into the pot. People are foremost worried about bread and butter issues. Cf. #4276 Chunguni yaingiayo..
L.43; V.,maneno. Words are silver, but answers are gold. Not words but results.
MM. Speaking is like silver, but replying is like gold.
. F.22.16; SM; KA. Hard words break no bones. Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me. F.
NS.17. Sharp teeth do not break a bone. Stay away from quarrels. NS. Cf. #1856.
. KA. Hard words break a bone. Hard words can hurt a person very deeply, as painful as the breaking of a bone.
NGU. Kind words are a blessing.

quote: Maneno mazuri  kama maua yana  rangi yake.
tail: NGU. Nice words are like flowers: they have their own color.
F.22.17; SWA.17; MARA 3. Pleasant words will draw a snake from its hole. With kind words one may calm down a dangerous person. It is easier to catch flies with honey than with vinegar. SWA.

SM; MARA 3. Sweet words will draw a snake from its hole. Usage in a newspaper: Pamoja na zana zao wanamuziki hawa wanaoweza kumtoa nyoka pangoni, si wengine bali na Wana Jikomoro.(Nchi Yetu #163, Julai 1978). With their instruments these musicians, who can draw snakes from their holes, are no others than the Wana Jikomoro.
NS. 22. A good word draws a snake from its hole.
KB.90. A kind word made a snake come out of its hole. To obtain something by trick or flattery.
B.1.29. Many words are like a disease. Chattering and talking nonsense are signs that the brain is giving way.
B.1.29. Many words are like a sickness.
T.243; SACL.,ukongo; AL 726. Many words are like a sickness. Talking too much is a weakness of old people. AL.
MA.284. Many words call forth a lot of disgrace. Talkativeness reveals one's faults, weaknesses. MA.
FSM.80. Many words consume the brain.

quote: Maneno  mengi ya kweli husemwa katika dhihaka.
tail: NGU. Many a true word is spoken jokingly. Dhihaka: mockery, ridicule, scorn.

quote: Maneno ni kama fumo yakitoka mdomoni hayarudi.
tail: MA.285. Words are like spears, once when they leave the lips they never come back. Watch what you are saying. MA. Cf. #1828.

quote: Maneno ya  mpole yampoza mwenye hasira
tail: . AL 817; AL, pole. Words spoken by a kind person pacify an angry one.
NGU. Laments are expressed by tears.

quote: Mbele ya  kusema uzungushe ulimi mara saba kinywani.
tail: KB.167. Before you speak, turn your tongue seven times in your mouth.

quote: Mche  mnyamavu: ana ngoma za midomo.
tail: T.253; SACL. 627; AL 765. Mistrust a taciturn person, that person has lips like a drum. Has lips for an oration. SACL..
FSM.104. Your gossiping mouth tells you what you really are. Deep inside you know what you really are.. Mmbeya or mmbea (from -umbea): tale-bearer, gosslp, scandal monger. T.
AL 1746. The table may be small, but the palavers are many. When unimportant things seem to be important.
RSP.77. Control your lips, to sleep in peace.

quote: Mja kiwa  sawa, kambiwa yu kombo.
tail: JK.131; AL 1397. Even when a person is straight, they will say there is something crooked with him. Even if the newcomer is correct, they'll say that he is imperfect. AL. A stranger is suspect and criticized. Mja. (from kuja, coming): a newcomer, a stranger. Mja or binadamu: a human being. KS., mja. Cf. #787; #884; #985; #986; #1481; #1838.
F.28.88. One who keeps silent lasts. F.
NGU. A sorcerer speaks not. Keeps silent about evil intent. Keeps away from people.
REK. A brave traveler has many tall stories. Uvumi: gossip, rumors, tales.
KS; SM. One who is not afraid to be slandered is a fool. Kwambwa or kusemwa: spoken evil of. Nyamba, duni: a fool
JK.139. The one who does not have any [word] has God. "God suffices as a witness." Koran 24,6, Eloquence is not necessary.
MM. If you have no one, you have God.
FSM 134. One who is spat upon often enough gets intoxicated. If somebody is told a thing over and over again that person will finally believe it.
FSM.132. One who does good does not speak about it; if that person does speak [about it] that one does not do [good] deeds. Also used regarding people who talk a lot but perform poorly.

quote: Mtu huanza  kumega tonge kwanza, haanzi kupanua kinywa.
tail: NGU. A person starts breaking a piece of bread first, the mouth is not opened first. Think before speaking or doing things. Wait for your time. In due time.
. J.,chonga; B.l. 19; T.340; KB.,chongea. A person is betrayed by one's own tongue. A shut mouth keeps one from strife.
. FSM.190. The tongue betrays the head. Puts the head in trouble. Cf. #1803.

quote: Mtu  kikwambia neno, sijibu upesi mno.
tail: JKP. If someone tells you something, do not answer too quickly.
MA.382. A blind person is not asked, what do you see. Cf. #1703.
JK.133. A gentleman is [as good as his] word. Cf. #916.
KA. A slanderer of your friend sends you to tell your friend. Don't talk bad to someone's friend, because that person will tell the friend.
TAA 21; AL 760. Speaking evil about someone to your friend is the same as sending your friend on a mission to tell that person about the bad thing you said. Mwamba: slander.
NGU. Tell it to the person who is willing to listen.
NGU. A child that slanders another gives away leftover food [in order to pacify the one slandered].
FSM.154. One who walks in silence quarrels with nobody. Moreover, people respect the silent one because that person is more difficult to understand. FSM.
CM.51; B.1.52; F.35.157. A noisy person has no message.

FSM.158. One who goes to the meeting place will not come back with nothing. Going to the place where people gather to talk things over will enlighten us about happenings, whether true or false. However, because it is also a place of gossip, it can also mean that if you go and listen to gossip, you'll return with many problems.
KB.217; AL 128. When someone wears mourning clothes you don't ask why. Chakavu: old, spoiled, torn or discarded.
NGU. A joke needs its own time and place.
. KB.231. If you control your mouth you have much prudence.

quote: Natuone  ndipo twambe, kusikia si kuona.
tail: F.38.2. Let us see, then we can talk, hearing is not seeing. Cf. #1333.

quote: Neno jiwi  ni jeraha la moyo.
tail: KA. A bad word wounds the heart.

quote: Neno jiwi ni  kidonda cha moyo.
tail: MARA 2. An evil word wounds the heart. It does not heal easily, is not soon forgotten. Evil words build a lasting hatred.
RSP.21. I saw it, I saw it! They will make you a witness. Do not talk too much, you might be called to account for it. JK.

KA. Flattery is tasty. Idle praise is sweet. It is better to use kind words than words that hurt. Nyama ya ulimi: meat of the tongue, [idiom], flattery, empty words of praise in order to obtain a favor.

quote: Panya  anasema na mwamba, mwenye neno halijui.
tail: PM.303.12. The mouse said to the joist, the one we talk about suspects nothing. We are often ignorant of what people say or think of us.
T.454. It came to pass and it happened ... A phrase used in starting a tale. The end of the story: Kigano na kihadithi kikomele hapo. The little tale and little story ends here. T.
KB.262. Where there is an abundance of words, sin also is not lacking.
NGU. Say what you know. Don't say what you don't know.

quote: Shairi ni  maneno mazuri ya mawazo matamu.
tail: NGU. A poem is made of nice words and fine thoughts.
F.43.4; B.1.64. A pit [dug by] the tongue cannot be covered up by the hand. A word is past recalling.
NGU. A big weapon is the tongue. For cure and harm.

quote: Simba  mwenda kimya ndiye alaye nyama.
tail: F.44.12; SACL.382; KA; CM.42; NGU. The lion which moves silently is the one that eats the meat.
JK.145. A lion that hunts does not roar. JK.
FSM.93. A roaring lion is not a hunter.
NGU. A roaring lion is tired of hunting.
KA; SM. I don't vomit bile and come back to lick it. A word spoken cannot be taken back. About nasty words or deeds. Used, e.g., in a divorce.
NGU. The poison of a word is a word. Abuse going from bad to worse.

quote: Tajiri  akinong'ona husikika, maskini akipayuka hasikiki.
tail: REK. A rich person whispering is heard, a poor person fulminating is not heard.

quote: Tone  hutoza dosari ambalo ndoo tele haitoshi kuliondoa.
tail: EM t17. A drop can cause a stain that a bucketful of water cannot remove. Stain here represents an insult or bad word.

quote: Ukiona  neno, usinene neno: ukinena neno litakujia neno.
tail: J.,nena; SACL.676; B.1.29; MEM.91; NGU. If you see anything, do not say anything; if you say anything, something will happen to you.

quote: Ukiona neno,  usiposema neno, hupatikani na neno.
tail: F.46.7; A.140, T.525, L.99, V.49,hufikwi na neno; SAM.23.4. If you see something and say nothing, you will not suffer.
AL 766. If you move your tongue too much, your mouth will be harmed. The silent people and the babblers are asocial people.
. JKP. When you tell news, do not speak in riddles. Do not slander by allusion. JKP.
CM.50. The tongue has no remedy. Wounds inflicted by the tongue are incurable. Cf. #855, #856.
F.47.17; L.102, B.2.24; CM.50; H.105; T.532; SWA.38; J.,ulimi; MARA.16; NS.72; JK.138; V.13; KB.316; KS, mfupa. A tongue has no bone. Is unreliable. Word and deed are two. KB. Cf. #854, #856.
NGU. The tongue cures itself. You cannot put medicine on the tongue. Cf. #2047.
NGU. The tongue endangers the body. By provoking fights.
EM u17. Sweet language makes the elephant leave the plantation. Gentle coaxing often removes a danger. Cf. #1833.

quote: Ulimi  ukuchome kwa chakula, sio kwa maneno.
tail: EM u18. Food should burn your tongue, but not words. It's better to be hurt than hurt others.
EM u19. The tongue is surrounded by a stone fort. The tongue should be guarded within the wall of teeth.
AL 728. The tongue stays in the middle of the teeth. We are surrounded by enemies. Be careful of what we say.
. F.47.18. The tongue hurts more than the teeth. Cf. #1833, 1854.

quote: Usijitende  ng'ombe, ukatoa ulimi kutia puani.
tail: T.553. Do not act like a cow, sticking out your tongue and putting it into your nose. Do not put back into your nose what has come from your mouth, [i.e., a promise]. T. Said of somebody who does not keep promises, or denies what has been said.
T.553. Don't act the cow!

quote: Usikaange  mbuyu ukawaachia wenye meno watafune
tail: . F.48.33. Do not roast baobab kernels and let those who have teeth chew them. Don't start quarrels among other people by telling tales. F. Cf. #? "If you roast maize [mbisi - popcorn] you roast it for people who have teeth". Racial proverbs 586.148. Kaanga mbuyu: to deceive, to start a quarrel. Idiom.
JKP. Do not speak loudly so that a passerby hear it.
AL 767. If you do not speak up, you'll get thin. A silent person is pushed back and cannot hope to have a happy life. AL.

quote: Usiseme ni  haki unachoweza kuuliza kwa upendeleo.
tail: NGU. Don't say that it is your right if you can ask for it as a favor.
NGU. Don't speak about what happened on the road before investigating. Tangaza: publish, advertise; proclaim
EM w1. Let them speak in daytime, at night they will sleep. Those who speak against you cannot speak all the time. So you should not mind so much. EM.
FSM.201. Where words are spoken there also words are heard. Be careful what you say. Make your good ideas heard.

quote: Wasemayo  ni kweli; hata hayajafika, sharti yafike.
tail: AL 1892. Spoken words are efficacious; even if not yet realized, they surely will come through. AL. Cf. #1742.
4410. Wasikilize wote wasemao lakini washangilie wachache wasemao busara tu. NGU. They may listen to all the speakers, but applause [only] the few who make sense.
KA Those who speak a lot during the day, are tired [sleep] at night. Slanderers get tired at the end. So don't worry too much about them.

quote: Watu ni  gamba, hawakosi la kwamba.
tail: JKP. People are like gramophones, they never stop talking. Gamba [chombo kitoacho sauti]: an instrument that speaks. Kwamba or kuamba or kusema: to speak.
V.,amba, People are chatterboxes; if they do not talk in public they do it in secret. Or: If they do not converse they talk nonsense. Said of the Swahili. V.
JK.131. People have many tongues. Referring to the talk of the town. JK. Cf. #1828.
EM y1. I mean, I mean, does not break a bone. Empty words do not achieve anything. EM.
FSM.204. What is said and what is done are different.

quote: Yateue ya  usemi, na utawale ulimi.
tail: JKP. Choose eloquent words and control your tongue. Teua: choose.
